***"From R to Manuscript"***

`report`'s primary goal is to bridge the gap between R's output and the formatted results contained in your manuscript. It automatically produces reports of models and dataframes according to **best practice** guidelines (*e.g.,* [APA](https://www.apastyle.org/)'s style guide), ensuring **standardization** and **quality** in results reporting.




```{r eval=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(report)

# Example
model <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data=iris)
report(model)
```
```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
# Example
lm(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data=iris) %>% 
  report() %>% 
  to_text(width=100)
```

## Report all the things <a href=https://easystats.github.io/Psycho.jl/latest/><img src="https://www.memecreator.org/static/images/templates/2776.jpg" height="100"></a>

### General Workflow

The `report` package works in a two step fashion. First, you create a `report` object with the `report()` function (which takes different arguments depending on the type of object you are reporting). Then, this report object can be displayed either textually, using `to_text()`, or as a table, using `to_table()`. Moreover, you can access a more detailed (but less digested) version of the report using `to_fulltext()` and `to_fulltable()`. Finally, `to_values()` makes it easy to access all the internals of a model.

### Features

The `report()` function works on a variety of models, as well as dataframes:

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
# Dataframe report
report(iris)
```
```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
print(report(iris), width=100)
```

These reports nicely work within the [*tidyverse*](https://github.com/tidyverse) workflow:

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
# Correlation report
cor.test(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Petal.Length) %>% 
  report()
```
```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
print(report(cor.test(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Petal.Length)), width=100)
```

You can also create tables with the `to_table()` and `to_fulltable()` functions:


```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
# Table report for a linear model
lm(Sepal.Length ~ Petal.Length + Species, data=iris) %>% 
  report() %>% 
  to_table()
```


Finally, you can also find more details using `to_fulltext()`:

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
# Full report for a Bayesian logistic mixed model with effect sizes
library(rstanarm)

stan_glmer(vs ~ mpg + (1|cyl), data=mtcars, family="binomial") %>% 
  report(standardize="smart", effsize="cohen1988") %>% 
  to_fulltext()
```
```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(rstanarm)
rstanarm::stan_glmer(vs ~ mpg + (1|cyl), data=mtcars, family="binomial", refresh = 0) %>% 
  report(standardize="smart", effsize="cohen1988") %>% 
  to_fulltext(width=100)
```

## Examples

### Supported Packages

Currently supported objects by **report** include [`cor.test`](https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-patched/library/stats/html/cor.test.html), [`t.test`](https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/stats/html/t.test.html), [`correlation`](https://github.com/easystats/correlation), [`glm`](https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/stats/html/glm.html), [`lme4::merMod`](https://github.com/lme4/lme4/), [`rstanarm::stanreg`](https://github.com/stan-dev/rstanarm), [`estimate`](https://github.com/easystats/estimate).

### *t*-tests and correlations

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
t.test(mtcars$mpg ~ mtcars$am) %>% 
  report()
```
```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
t.test(mtcars$mpg ~ mtcars$am) %>% 
  report() %>% 
  to_text(width=100)
```


### Miscellaneous

#### Report participants details

```{r message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
data <- data.frame("Age" = c(22, 23, 54, 21),
                   "Sex" = c("F", "F", "M", "M"))

paste(report_participants(data, spell_n = TRUE),
      "were recruited in the study by means of torture and coercion.")
```
